com.google.android.agera

Interface Repository<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Observable, Supplier<T>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    MutableRepository<T>, Reservoir<T>

    public interface Repository<T>
extends Observable, Supplier<T>
    An Observable Supplier of data.

    As the data contained in the Repository changes, the added Updatables will be notified of these changes and the Supplier will return the new data.

    A Repository can either be implemented as

    • Direct - The contained data is always available, or can be calculated synchronously
    • Deferred - The contained data is calculated/fetched asynchronously

    A Repository thus have two primary states (in addition to the different state of the data it contains)

    • Inactive - There are no added Updatables and the Repository is deferred. The Repository may choose to free up data to save memory and the data it returns calling Supplier.get() will not be fresh.
    • Active - There are added Updatables or the Repository is direct. The Repository is keeping it's data updated based on external events.

    A direct Repository is always active. A deferred Repository is inactive until an Updatable is added. As the Repository becomes active, the added Updatables will be notified and the fresh data can be fetched using Supplier.get().

    When using the Repository interface it is not possible to know if the implementation is direct or deferred. It is therefore important to always add an Updatable to wake up the Repository when it is needed.

    • Method Summary

      • Methods inherited from interface com.google.android.agera.Observable

        addUpdatable, removeUpdatable

      • Methods inherited from interface com.google.android.agera.Supplier

        get
